PrimEcoSys: North American Warm Desert Active and Stabilized Dune

habitat_description:
This species occurs in the Coachella Valley, Riverside County, California (Pough 1973; Stebbins 2003). In 1980, USFWS reported an estimated area occupied by this lizard to be about 839 square kilometers. A more current approximation of the range extent for this species is much needed.

Its habitat consists of loose, fine sands that are suitable for burrowing. It is also known to occupy abandoned rodent burrows. The vegetation situations it is associated with include sandy dunes with patches of creosote bush and other scrubby plants (Stebbins 2003). More specifically, it has been reported that shelter is obtained through perennial native plants and the annual plant commonly known as bugseed (Dicoria canascens), which is vital in providing plant and insect foods, as well as shelter (Durtsche 1995 (As referenced by Natureserve.org).

Found in xeric areas characterized by creosote bush, but shelter and food is also provided by perennial plants and the annual plant Dicoria canescens.
